passage_text: Healthy urine may have a mild smell but generally does not have a foul odor. In some cases, an unusual or strong urine odor may be due to benign conditions that are not harmful, such as eating certain foods or taking certain medications.
Urethritis (inflammation of the urethra) is also a cause for foul and sulfur smelling urine. You really should go to a doctor. He/She will most likely prescribe Doxycycline or Zirythromax.

When urine persistently smells bad or has a foul, strong or unusual odor, it may be caused by an underlying disease, disorder or condition. Urine odor can be a symptom of a variety of conditions, including infection, inflammation, or other conditions of the urinary tract (kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra).

you voted. Answer by kd97 (733). Foul smelling urine or discharge could be the symptom of an STD, or it could be from a UTI (urinary tract infection) Medications taken daily can also cause a bad smell. Odor when urinating can also be from a kidney infection, or a bladder infection.

Normal urine is clear and has a straw-yellow color. While the odor of urine can vary somewhat, in most cases, it does not have a strong smell. With dehydration, the urine is more concentrated and may have a stronger ammonia scent than normal.

The presence of bacteria in the urine, such as with a urinary tract infection (UTI), can affect the appearance and smell of urine. When there is an infection in the urinary tract, the urine may take on a foul-smelling odor as well as appear cloudy or bloody.
Foul smelling urine or discharge could be the symptom of an STD, or it could be from a UTI (urinary tract infection) Medications taken daily can also cause a bad smell.

Dear Reader, Normally, urine doesn't have much of a smell to it. If you're dehydrated and your urine becomes overly concentrated, it can have a stronger-than-usual scent. Vitamins and certain foods (asparagus, for example) can give urine an unusual smell. Infection can cause the urine to smell unpleasant.

See your GP if: 1  You have symptoms of a urinary tract infection (UTI) , such as pain or a burning sensation when urinating and a need to urinate often. 2  This is the most likely cause of unexplained foul-smelling urine.
